content.text:
# List of presidents of the United States who lost reelection__disambig_1

is the first president to have lost a re-election.]]
The president of the United States is the head of state and head of government of the United States, indirectly elected to a four-year term via the Electoral College. The president is eligible for re-election, but since 1951 under the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution of the United States cannot be re-elected twice (no person may serve more than two full terms as president or one term if they have served over two years of a partial term).
List
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|-
! Term in office !! President !! Lost election !! Winning successor !! Notes
|- id="USA"
| 1797–1801 ||  || 1800 United States presidential election
|  || Adams placed third behind Jefferson and his running mate Aaron Burr. Jefferson narrowly won a contingent election in the U.S. House of Representatives.
|-
| 1825–1829 ||  || 1828 United States presidential election
|  || Jackson previously won a plurality of the popular vote against Adams in the 1824 presidential election but lost a contingent election.
|-
| rowspan="2" | 1837–1841 || rowspan="2" |  || 1840 United States presidential election
|  || Van Buren is the only president to have lost two re-elections.
|-
| 1848 United States presidential election
|  || Van Buren ran under the Free Soil Party. He's also the first president to run for a non-consecutive term.
|-
| 1850–1853 ||  || 1856 United States presidential election
| rowspan="2" |  || Fillmore ran under both the Whig Party and the Know Nothing Party.
|-
| 1853–1857 ||  || 1856 Democratic National Convention || Pierce unsuccessfully tried to get the Democratic party nomination, and lost to James Buchanan, who went on to win the elections.
|-
| 1865–1869 ||  || 1868 Democratic National Convention
|  || Johnson unsuccessfully tried to get the Democratic party nomination, and lost to Horatio Seymour, who lost the elections to Ulysses S. Grant.
|-
| 1869–1877 ||  || 1880 Republican National Convention
|  || Grant lost the 1880 nomination for the Republican party presidential ticket, he narrowly lost to James A. Garfield, who went on to win the elections.
|-
| 1881–1885 ||  || 1884 Republican National Convention
|  || While unlikely to win the nomination, Arthur nonetheless ran for the Republican Party nomination and lost it to James G. Blaine, who lost the elections to Grover Cleveland.
|-
| 1885–1889 ||  || 1888 United States presidential election
|  || Cleveland lost the 1888 presidential election, but won the 1892 United States presidential election, becoming the first U.S. president to serve nonconsecutive terms.
|-
| 1889–1893 ||  || 1892 United States presidential election
|  || A rematch of the presidential election four years earlier.
|-
| 1901–1909 ||  || rowspan="2" |1912 United States presidential election || rowspan="2" |  || Roosevelt ran under the Progressive Party.
|-
| 1909–1913 ||
| Taft also ran against former President Theodore Roosevelt for the Republican nomination. After Taft won Roosevelt launched his own presidential campaign under the Progressive Party. Taft came in third behind both Wilson and Roosevelt.
|-
| 1929–1933 ||  || 1932 United States presidential election
|  || Hoover also hoped to get a nomination at both the 1936 and 1940 Republican National Concentions, but ultimately didn't get one.
|-
| 1974–1977 ||  || 1976 United States presidential election
|  || Former Georgia governor Jimmy Carter and Minnesota senator Walter Mondale narrowly defeated the Republican ticket of incumbent president Gerald Ford and Kansas senator Bob Dole. Ford is also the only president not to have been elected in an election.
|-
| 1977–1981 ||  || 1980 United States presidential election
|  || Carter was the first elected president to lose a re-election bid since Herbert Hoover in 1932.
|-
| 1989–1993 ||  || 1992 United States presidential election
|  || Some speculated that Ross Perot, the unsuccessful third candidate in the presidential race, cost Bush the election.
|-
| 2017–2021 ||  || 2020 United States presidential election
|  ||Trump refused to concede, alleging fraud, but ultimately losing multiple post-election lawsuits before 86 judges. The counting of the Electoral College votes by Congress on January 6, 2021, was briefly stopped when rioters stormed the Capitol building. Joe Biden's victory was confirmed when Congress reconvened hours later. Trump and Biden were initially presumptive nominees in the 2024 United States presidential election until Biden withdrew. Trump subsequently won the 2024 presidential election and is ineligible to run for another term due to the Twenty-second Amendment.
|}
